results.description: This image was created in 2014, by CDC) Epidemiologist, Mary Alleman, M.P.H., Ph.D., during an outbreak of wild poliovirus in the Central African nation of Cameroon, specifically, at a bus station in Bafoussam, the regional capital of West Region, Cameroon. The photograph depicts two vaccination team members on the right, one wearing a yellow apron, and one a yellow hat, as they were in the process of vaccinating a child, who had just exited an arriving bus.

This image depicts a number of objects of public health concern that were seized by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), San Francisco Quarantine Station. These skulls had been shipped from Banaue Ifugao province in the Philippines, and were seized by the CDC due to violations of the foreign quarantine regulations, as specified in 42CFR71 regarding the importations of human remains.

Created in April, 2012, by CDC Health Scientist, Óscar Tarragó, M.D., M.P.H., this scene was taking place in a sexually transmitted infection (STI) clinic in Guatemala, and depicts a patient who is having her blood drawn, by phlebotomist, Ana Chic, which would then be tested for STIs and HIV. As part of the VICITS program (Surveillance and Control for Sexually Transmitted Infections Spanish acronym), this clinic serves as a model training center for the country.

Created by CDC Sr. Systems Analyst, Julian Buckmaster, this image depicts a line of Haitian school children who had gathered in order to receive a two-drug treatment for lymphatic filariasis (LF), which was being administered by community members seated at a desk on the right. This effort took place in Haiti during an annual school-based mass drug administration (MDA), a form of preventative chemotherapy, for lymphatic filariasis.

Created in May, 2015, by CDC, Epidemiologist, Caitlin M. Worrell, M.P.H., this image depicts a Haitian child holding on to his blood tube during a transmission assessment survey (TAS) that was being conducted in the Dondon Commune in Northern Haiti.

Captured August 25, 2011, this photograph depicts what was a food distribution waiting area organized due to a nutritional health emergency, which was located in Wajir County, Kenya. At this particular moment, each holding a small plastic pail, this group of Kenyan children were in line waiting to have their pails filled with much need foods during this time of famine.

Taken in Salima, Malawi, by CDC Medical Officer, Manoj Menon, MD, MPH, this image depicts two children, one proudly holding a bottle of water, and a toy cell phone that he made out of dirt and seeds. Dr. Menon tells, "I was working on a safe water project, interviewing households regarding access to safe drinking water, knowledge, and prevention of diarrheal diseases.  The bottle of water represents one potential option for safe drinking water.  The cell phone revealed his creativity and hope."

Created in November, 2014, by CDC Microbiologist, Tara Sealy, this photograph depicted fellow CDC Microbiologists, Aridth Gibbons and Brandy Russell, while they were performing analyses inside the Viral Special Pathogens Branch, Ebola "hot lab" located in Bo, Sierra Leone.

Created in March, 2015, by CDC Epidemiologist, Rebecca Hall, M.P.H., this image depicts the "Survivor Wall", at the Bong Ebola Treatment Unit (ETU), located in Bong County, Liberia. International Medical Corps (IMC) workers in the ETU were overjoyed, when the number of handprints of Ebola survivors surpassed the initial space made available on the Wall. The Bong ETU had admitted over 400 patients since it opened in September, 2014.

This image, entitled, "Using Death to Inform the Living", was created in June, 2015, by the friend of U.S. Public Health Service, Commissioned Corps, LT Lauren Brewer, while they were visiting the Wake Memorial Cemetery located in Cary, North Carolina.

Captured in the Indian city of Forbesganj, in the Bihar State District of Araria, November, 2009, this photograph depicts Dr. Mohan Kohli, of India's National Polio Surveillance Project (NPSP), training a group of external monitors and field volunteers, on the use of an Optical Mark Recognition (OMR) form. The form provides an innovative method for capturing data electronically, eliminating manual data entry, thus providing the polio program information in a much timelier manner.

This 2013 photograph depicts a bedroom located in a Kumi, Uganda home, wherein, an insecticide-treated bednet had been rolled up above the wood frame bed beneath. When used properly, the bednet would prevent malaria-transmitting mosquitoes from lighting on the skin of potential hosts, in order to obtain their blood meal, and in doing so, transmit the malarial parasite to their sleeping victims.

Created by CDC Public Health Advisor, Kris Khan, M.S., R.N. in the Program Services Branch of the Division of Cancer Prevention and Control, the image depicts a scene in a Venice, Italy alleyway, whereupon, a number of posters had been affixed to the alley walls. One of the posters encouraged women to participate in a mammographic screening exam, which captured Khan's attention.

A "quick shot" from a moving vehicle, on a roadway in Abuja, Nigeria, captured the type of improvised mobility system implemented by many individuals afflicted by lower body paralysis, which is often a result of Polio, in this region of the developing world. This man's colorful ensemble represents the national colors of Nigeria, while reflecting the enthusiasm, and exuberance that punctuates life and work in Nigeria.

Captured in the Indian State of Uttar Pradesh, this image was created in 2000, by CDC Nurse Epidemiologist, Christine Zahniser, B.S.N., M.P.H., during the country's celebration of National Immunization Day. Each of the children, or scouts, depicted here, were wearing their "No Polio" headbands, clearly advertising the day's celebratory activities, as they clamored for a position before the camera lens.

Captured in 2007, by Alison Smith with the National Center for HIV/AIDS, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and TB Prevention (NCHHSTP), Global AIDS Program, Epidemiology and Strategic Information Branch, while in the Girba refugee camp in rural eastern Sudan, this image depicts a little boy kneeling at the edge of a muddy pond, about to drink from this unsafe water source, which is formed when rainwater collects outside the village, and in which nearby villagers wash their camels, water cattle, and bathe.

This image was created in 2010, by CDC, Health Scientist, Aaron Sussell, Ph.D., M.P.H., C.I.H., with the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), and depicts an oil spill response team in the process of removing tar balls from a Destin, Florida beach.

In this image, created in February, 2015, by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Epidemic Intelligence Service (EIS) Officer, Alaine Kathryn Knipes, Ph.D., Mr. Metellus, a technician with Haiti's ministry of health, was performing rapid diagnostic tests for lymphatic filariasis (LF), while seated inside a rural classroom located in the Nippes Department of Haiti.

This photograph, captured in 2005 by guest researcher, Sung-Chul Seo, depicts a scientist, wearing his complement of personal protective equipment (PPE), while in the process of conducting a mold investigation of a home that had been ravaged by flooding as a result of Hurricane Katrina.

Captured in 2007, by Mary Glenshaw, Ph.D., M.P.H. in Savelugu, Ghana, this image depicts a Guinea worm extraction procedure being done on a young Ghanaian girl, as live worms are being pulled from the skin on the girl's abdomen.

Magnified 500X, this photomicrograph depicted some of the histopathologic changes associated with an infection found in a brain tissue specimen due to the presence of free-living amoebae of the genus, Naegleria.

This image was created in 2009, by CDC Public Health Advisor, Phyllis Nichols, M.P.H., a staff member in the Healthy Communities Program Office (formerly the Steps Program), in the Division of Adult and Community Health. It depicts a number of seniors at a Philadelphia, Chinese Senior Center, participating in CDC's Healthy Communities' Program, "Steps to a HealthierUS". Here, these attendees were doing Tai Chi, as a way to increase access to opportunities for physical fitness.

In this image, created in February, 2015, by CDC Epidemic Intelligence Service (EIS) Officer, Alaine Kathryn Knipes, Ph.D., two laboratory technicians with Haiti's ministry of health (MoH), Mr. Dorelus and Mrs. Byzette, were processing blood samples in order to test for lymphatic filariasis (LF) and malaria, using rapid diagnostic tests in a rural classroom located in the Nippes Department of Haiti.

Captured August, 2006, in the Nairobi, Kenya division known as Kibera, by CDC Microbiologist, Stephanie Schwartz, this image depicts two children offering the camera a welcoming smile, as CDC visitors were exploring this area of surveillance as a part of a Global Disease Detection (GDD) program.

"This picture [of a racing camel and its owner], was taken during an Investigation in 2009 in Alkhurma, Saudi Arabia. Alkhurma virus [had been] isolated from patients suffering from hemorrhagic fever", says Pierre Rollin, M.D. "The virus is transmitted by ticks. At the request of the Saudi Ministry of Health, an investigation was done in January, 2010, leading to the launch of the Alkhurma virus national program including surveillance, and development of a diagnostic laboratory."

This image was created in August, 2014, on behalf of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Heath Scientist, and Special Assistant to the Director, Nancy S. Andrade, M.P.A., while in Equatorial Guinea, near the city of Niefang, during a polio vaccination campaign.

This image was created in August, 2014, by CDC, Health Scientist, Aaron Sussell, PhD, MPH, and depicts National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), Health Communication Specialist, Elizabeth Dalsey, from the Western States Offices, as she was interviewing members of a CALFire crew of young Hispanic firefighters, while at the French Fire,

This photograph was captured in front of a school located in western Cambodia's, Battambang province, and  shows a wagon carrying a group of young school children and their guardians. These children had been vaccinated against Japanese encephalitis (JE), and were holding up their right index fingers, which had been stained with gentian violet, and their immunization cards, verifying their participation in the campaign.

This image was created in 2007, by CDC, Public Health Advisor, Alison Smith, M.P.H. The photo depicts a number of pregnant women waiting to be given pre-natal blood tests in the refugee camp hospital laboratory. These women represent a mere fraction of the more than 130,000 refugees from the Ethiopian/Eritrean civil war living in the Kilo 26 refugee camp in rural eastern Sudan, where there is no electricity, running water, latrines, or clean drinking water.

This image depicts the lymphatic filariasis (LF) surveillance project coordinator, Sultan Mahmood Syeed, demonstrating to staff at a health facility in the Gaibandha District of Northern Bangladesh, the proper technique used to collect blood samples on filter paper. Data collected will help the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, identify and isolate possible sites of transmission, and provide evidence needed to support the verification of interruption of LF transmission in Bangladesh.
